climbs.name: Up the Corner and Around the Bend

content.description: Super fun problem with a lot of sick holds but super hard to find; don't even know how to explain locating it properly. Start on the outside low and swing around the corner to traverse upwards with sick jugs the whole way.
content.location: Walk the trail to the left of the rock formations to find this decently far away from all the rest of the problems up in a draw. Last I was there, there was a brush pile I believe was gathered by BLM people but no idea if it's still there. It's a fun climb if you can find it.

content.description: Fun climb on the back of the Just Go Up Boulder. Start low, using handholds mainly on the arete and popping up to some sweet jugs; finish with a sick top out. Careful on the downclimb, it's treacherous; best way we accomplished it was pad stacking and jumping off.
content.location: Back side of the Just Go Up Boulder, which is the first big one to the left of the main trail as you walk out of the parking lot.

content.description: Super fun but sandy traverse from high left to low right or vice versa. You'll probably need a brush to clean this one since it's usually pretty dusty but most of the holds are super solid so it's fun to monkey around on.
content.location: Walk down the main trail from the parking lot and swing a right around the Easy Peasey problem, can't miss it.

content.description: Fun little sit start. Start with hands matched on a big dish with feet pressed against low wall; spring up to grab sandstone pillar; use dishes to pop up to standing, then proceed vertical, grabbing a hidden pocket around left, then climb to top out. Super fun if sequenced right and great for beginners.
content.location: This will be on your right as you walk down the main trail before you hit the Big Boy Boulder.

content.description: This one is hard and I hate it. Beta is easy to figure out, start low left and go up right.
content.location: This is right in front of the big boy boulder's face.

content.description: Nothing too hard, sit start low right, finish high left, mounting the lip to top out. Good for beginners. (I know there are no orbs ok, please stop harassing me and my family)
content.location: As you walk from the parking lot, to the left and rear of the big boy boulder, partially hidden by another boulder and a tree.

content.description: Sketchy problem but super fun and high risk/reward. Start on right side of overhang, then traverse left and up with a gnarly final dyno to top out on a solid shelf. Hand holds prior to dyno may not be obvious pockets on the left face. Fall here without some serious pads and/or spotters and it could be pretty bad.
content.protection: Use a lot of pads my friend.
content.location: As you walk down the main trail to the bonfire pit area of the course, if you stand in the bonfire pit it will be your first boulder to your left, looks super unique and gnarly. Unfortunately covered in old paintball wax with some garbage probably on the bottom shelf.

content.description: Super fun jug traverse on the backside of the Big Boy Boulder. Start low right and traverse high left. Pretty easy but could be a sketchy fall.
content.location: Rear of the Big Boy Boulder.

content.description:
High Ball boulder but has my favorite holds I've ever encountered in all my years of climbing. Beautiful red rock, with slight choss: DO NOT GO OFF OF DEVELOPED ROUTE, COULD RESULT IN FALL AND DEATH

Two variations, start left side and go straight up or for the more enjoyable smooth variation start low right and gradually work your way up diagonally. You will encounter the holds I have included pictures of; again, just some of the most incredible solid holds I've ever encountered in nature.

Even if you don't top out, this boulder is a true pleasure to climb and swing around on. One of my favorite boulders I have ever climbed.
content.protection: High ball with no protection, stay on the developed holds or you could be calling it a night.
content.location: This is the biggest boulder in the initial area closest to the parking lot. If you stand in the bonfire pit, 'Just Go Up' will be on your left, parking lot will be behind you, and this boulder will be dead ahead.

content.description: The main beta is to stay straight verticle on the problem because if you treat it like a layback it turns into a V2.
content.location: This is the rear of the Sensei's Only boulder.

content.description: Circumnavigate this round boulder in a full 360 traverse. Super fun, and on certain portions is perfect for beginners but the crux is in the rear when you lose sight of your feet and it gets a bit technical. Super fun, solid traverse.
content.location: With the parking lot to your rear, this boulder is directly left and next to the Just Go Up boulder.

content.description: This is a right to left or left to right traverse with a wide variety of single-finger pockets to mess around on. Good clean boulder with an easy approach, great for first-time climbers to get comfortable on because it stays low the whole time.
content.location: Straight behind the Big Boy boulder, you have to walk up a little slope but its not hard to find or get to.

content.description: Super slabby easy boulder with a tree for some support; I have all my brand new climbing students start on this problem because it's super easy. Go right with your back to the tree and up to top out on some solid slightly slopey grabs up top. Downclimb is on the backside of the boulder.
content.location: First big boulder on your right as you head down the main trail from the parking lot.

content.description: Super fun one, I love this problem and it's perfect for beginners. Sit start low left, swing up to some solid jugs and top out high right to stand on a great vantage point of the whole area.
content.location: To the left of the Jugs Dot Com problem after walking up a little hill; part of the same big rock formation.
